behavioralAnchors.description: Focuses primarily on own team's backlog; limited visibility into cross-team dynamics or org-level priorities
Aware of adjacent teams' work and occasionally considers upstream/downstream impacts when planning
Regularly maps team objectives to org-level goals; identifies cross-team dependencies and raises them proactively
Drives alignment across multiple teams; connects disparate workstreams into coherent org narratives for leadership
Shapes org-wide systems thinking; proactively identifies and resolves cross-org tensions before they surface as blockers

gapQuestions: When did you last identify a cross-team dependency before it caused problems?
Can you articulate how your team's work connects to the company's top 3 priorities?
How often do you proactively reach out to peer teams to align on shared goals rather than reacting to conflicts?
When was the last time you changed your team's direction based on an org-level insight you surfaced yourself?

feedbackQuestions.question: How well do I connect my team's day-to-day work to the broader organizational strategy?
Does your manager clearly explain how your team's work fits into the larger company direction?
How effectively does this manager anticipate and communicate cross-team impacts from their team's work?
How well does this manager demonstrate understanding of org-level dynamics beyond their immediate team?

behavioralAnchors.description: Treats all requests as equally urgent; team frequently context-switches without clear rationale
Maintains a prioritized backlog but struggles to say no to new requests or make explicit tradeoff decisions
Uses clear frameworks (impact vs effort, strategic alignment) to prioritize; communicates tradeoffs to stakeholders
Proactively re-prioritizes based on changing business context; builds stakeholder consensus around difficult tradeoff decisions
Sets the strategic prioritization bar for the org; creates reusable frameworks that other teams adopt for their own planning

gapQuestions: What was the last significant project or request you explicitly deprioritized, and how did you communicate that decision?
Can you describe your framework for deciding what your team works on next quarter versus what gets deferred?
How do you handle conflicting priorities from multiple stakeholders, and when did you last navigate such a conflict?
When was the last time you killed or descoped an in-flight project based on new strategic information?

feedbackQuestions.question: How confident am I in my ability to make and defend prioritization tradeoffs under ambiguity?
Does your manager provide clear reasoning when priorities shift, so you understand what matters most and why?
When competing priorities arise, how effectively does this manager negotiate tradeoffs that balance multiple teams' needs?
How well does this manager align their team's priorities with the most impactful strategic bets for the organization?

behavioralAnchors.description: Defers all architecture decisions to senior ICs; cannot name the top 3 technical risks in their system; does not attend or contribute to design reviews
Understands basic system components and follows technical discussions; asks clarifying questions about scalability or reliability in design reviews; can diagram their team's service dependencies
Actively participates in design reviews; asks pointed questions about failure modes, operational burden, and migration paths
Guides teams toward architectures that balance business constraints with technical excellence; ensures designs account for operational realities
Shapes the org's technical vision and architectural principles; brokers cross-team architectural decisions that resolve systemic technical debt

gapQuestions: In the last design review you attended, what specific technical tradeoff did you push the team to think harder about?
How do you ensure that architectural decisions account for operational cost, not just development velocity?
When was the last time you challenged a technical approach proposed by a senior engineer, and what was the outcome?
How do you decide when to invest in paying down tech debt versus building new features, and what data informs that decision?

feedbackQuestions.question: How effectively do I contribute to technical design discussions beyond just approving what senior engineers propose?
Does your manager add meaningful perspective to architecture and design discussions, or do they primarily defer to others?
How well does this manager ensure their team's architectural decisions consider cross-team impacts and long-term maintainability?
How effectively does this manager balance technical ambition with practical delivery constraints in systems design?

behavioralAnchors.description: Team operates without consistent rituals; standups, retros, and planning happen sporadically or not at all; cannot state the purpose of any team ceremony
Basic operational cadences exist but are inconsistently enforced; blockers surface late in the sprint; sprint commitments missed >30% of the time
Runs a predictable operational rhythm with clear sprint goals, effective retros, and visible tracking of commitments and blockers
Continuously tunes team processes based on retrospective data; adapts rituals to team maturity and project phase without over-engineering
Establishes operational patterns that scale across teams; coaches other managers on building sustainable delivery cadences

gapQuestions: How often does your team deliver on sprint commitments, and what do you do when the pattern shows consistent over- or under-commitment?
What operational change did you make in the last quarter based on a retro insight, and what was the measurable impact?
How do you detect and unblock stalled work before it derails a milestone?
When was the last time you intentionally changed a team ritual because it stopped serving its purpose?

feedbackQuestions.question: How well do I maintain a healthy operational rhythm that helps my team deliver predictably without creating process overhead?
Are team rituals (standups, retros, planning) consistently useful, or do they feel like checkbox activities?
How reliably does this manager's team deliver on commitments and surface risks early?
How effectively does this manager run their team's operations to produce predictable, high-quality output?

behavioralAnchors.description: Primarily interacts within own team; rarely engages product, design, or other functions unless brought into a meeting
Has working relationships with immediate cross-functional partners but influence is limited to reactive problem-solving
Proactively builds relationships with product, design, and business stakeholders; co-creates roadmaps and jointly owns outcomes
Trusted advisor across functions; regularly shapes product direction and business decisions by bringing engineering perspective to strategic conversations
Drives cross-functional alignment at the org level; resolves inter-team conflicts and builds coalitions for complex multi-team initiatives

gapQuestions: When was the last time you influenced a product or business decision by proactively bringing an engineering insight to the table?
How do you build trust with cross-functional partners who have competing priorities?
Can you describe a situation where you brokered agreement between engineering and another function on a contentious tradeoff?
How do you manage upward â€” ensuring your skip-level and cross-functional sponsors understand your team's impact and advocate for your priorities?

feedbackQuestions.question: How effectively do I build influence with cross-functional partners beyond my direct engineering team?
Does your manager effectively represent engineering's perspective and needs to product, design, and other partners?
How well does this manager collaborate across functions to drive shared outcomes rather than optimizing only for engineering?
How effectively does this manager build cross-functional relationships and drive alignment on shared objectives?

behavioralAnchors.description: Conducts 1:1s infrequently or without structure; provides little feedback beyond annual reviews; team members unclear on growth paths
Holds regular 1:1s and provides occasional feedback but lacks a systematic approach to individual development planning
Maintains active development plans for each report; gives timely, specific feedback tied to observable behaviors and career goals
Creates stretch opportunities calibrated to individual growth edges; develops engineers into tech leads and future managers through deliberate sponsorship
Builds a talent development culture where coaching cascades; alumni consistently credit this manager as pivotal to their career trajectory

gapQuestions: For each of your direct reports, can you articulate their top growth area and what specific opportunity you have created to address it?
When was the last time you gave difficult, constructive feedback that led to a meaningful behavior change?
How do you balance supporting an underperformer with maintaining the team's overall velocity and morale?
Which of your reports is closest to a promotion, and what specific evidence gap remains?

feedbackQuestions.question: How consistently do I invest in the growth and development of each individual on my team, not just the high performers?
Does your manager give you actionable feedback regularly, and do you feel they are actively invested in your career growth?
How effectively does this manager develop talent on their team, and do their engineers grow visibly over time?
How well does this manager identify and develop future leaders on their team through coaching and sponsorship?

behavioralAnchors.description: Presents decisions after the fact with little context; stakeholders feel surprised or uninformed about key tradeoffs
Communicates decisions clearly but does not proactively frame the alternatives considered or the risks of each option
Frames decisions with clear options, tradeoffs, and recommendations; tailors communication to the audience's context and concerns
Builds decision frameworks that help stakeholders make faster, higher-quality choices; anticipates objections and addresses them preemptively
Sets the communication standard for the org; decision memos and escalation frameworks they create are adopted as organizational templates

gapQuestions: When was the last time you wrote a decision document that included explicit alternatives, risks, and a clear recommendation?
How do you adjust your communication style when presenting to executives versus your engineering team?
Can you recall a decision that went poorly because stakeholders were not adequately informed of the tradeoffs?
What is your process for documenting important decisions so that future team members understand not just what was decided, but why?

feedbackQuestions.question: How effectively do I frame decisions so that stakeholders can quickly understand the tradeoffs and make informed choices?
Does your manager clearly communicate the reasoning behind major decisions, including what alternatives were considered?
How well does this manager communicate technical decisions and tradeoffs to non-technical stakeholders?
How effectively does this manager frame and communicate decisions, especially when escalating issues or proposing changes?

behavioralAnchors.description: Reacts to incidents without defined roles or process; post-mortems blame individuals or don't happen; on-call page volume unknown
Participates in incident response but roles are ad hoc; post-mortems happen inconsistently with <50% action item completion; on-call load tracked but not actively managed
Runs blameless postmortems consistently; ensures action items are tracked and completed; maintains up-to-date runbooks and on-call rotations
Uses incident patterns to drive proactive reliability investments; builds a team culture where reliability is a first-class engineering concern
Shapes org-wide incident management practices; establishes reliability review processes and SLO frameworks that prevent classes of incidents

gapQuestions: What percentage of your postmortem action items from the last quarter are completed, and how do you track them?
How do you decide when to invest in reliability work versus feature development?
When was the last time your team had a repeat incident caused by an unaddressed root cause, and what did you change?
How do you prepare your team for on-call, and what do you do when on-call burden becomes unsustainable?

feedbackQuestions.question: How well do I balance reactive incident response with proactive reliability investment for my team's services?
Does your manager ensure the team learns from incidents and follows through on postmortem action items?
How effectively does this manager's team handle incidents, and do their services improve in reliability over time?
How well does this manager manage operational risk and drive reliability improvements across their domain?

behavioralAnchors.description: No delivery metrics tracked; team health is anecdotal; cannot state deployment frequency, lead time, or change failure rate
Basic metrics exist but are checked infrequently; dashboards built but not used for decisions; metrics used to report status upward, not to diagnose problems
Defines and tracks outcome-oriented metrics (lead time, deployment frequency, customer impact); uses data to surface problems and inform planning
Builds dashboards and reporting that connect engineering activity to business results; uses metrics to tell compelling stories in leadership forums
Establishes measurement frameworks adopted across the org; drives a data-informed culture where teams self-correct based on leading indicators

gapQuestions: What are the top 3 metrics you use to assess your team's health and effectiveness, and when did you last act on what they told you?
How do you measure the business impact of your team's engineering work beyond story points or tickets closed?
Can you point to a decision you changed or a project you stopped because the data showed it was not delivering expected outcomes?

feedbackQuestions.question: How effectively do I use data and metrics to drive decisions rather than relying on intuition or anecdote?
Does your manager use metrics fairly and transparently to assess team progress, rather than as a punitive tool?
How well does this manager use data to communicate their team's impact and inform cross-team decisions?
How effectively does this manager measure and communicate the outcomes and impact of their team's work?

behavioralAnchors.description: Accepts all incoming work without evaluating team capacity; team is chronically overcommitted and individuals are stretched thin
Aware of capacity constraints but struggles to push back on scope or make explicit tradeoff proposals to leadership
Maintains a clear picture of team capacity; makes explicit tradeoff proposals when new work arrives and negotiates scope effectively
Proactively reallocates resources based on shifting priorities; builds flexible team structures that can absorb change without burnout
Optimizes resource allocation across multiple teams; influences headcount and investment decisions with data-driven capacity models

gapQuestions: When was the last time you said no to a request or proposed a scope reduction because your team was at capacity?
How do you model your team's capacity, and how accurate has it been over the past two quarters?
Can you describe a time you reallocated engineers between projects mid-quarter, and how you managed the disruption?
How do you balance investing in long-term technical health versus short-term delivery pressure?

feedbackQuestions.question: How well do I manage my team's capacity to ensure sustainable delivery without chronic overcommitment?
Does your manager protect the team from overcommitment and make thoughtful tradeoffs when new work is added?
How effectively does this manager allocate resources and negotiate scope when competing demands arise?
How well does this manager balance resource allocation across competing priorities while maintaining team sustainability?

behavioralAnchors.description: Hiring is ad hoc; job descriptions are generic; interviews lack structure; new hires receive minimal onboarding beyond access setup
Uses structured interviews but does not calibrate hiring bar across interviewers; onboarding covers logistics but lacks a ramp-up plan
Designs roles with clear success criteria; runs calibrated interview loops; provides 30/60/90-day onboarding plans with defined milestones
Builds hiring pipelines that consistently attract diverse, high-caliber candidates; onboarding produces independently effective engineers within 60 days
Shapes org-wide hiring standards and interviewer training programs; designs role architectures that create clear career progression across the engineering org

gapQuestions: How long does it take a new hire on your team to ship their first meaningful contribution, and what have you done to shorten that timeline?
When did you last redesign a role or job description to better reflect the actual work and attract the right candidates?
How do you ensure consistency and fairness across interviewers on your hiring panels?
What is your process for evaluating whether your onboarding is effective, and what did you change based on that evaluation?

feedbackQuestions.question: How effectively do I design roles, run hiring processes, and onboard new team members to set them up for success?
Was your onboarding experience well-structured, and did you feel supported in ramping up to full productivity?
How well does this manager hire and onboard engineers who integrate effectively with cross-functional teams?
How effectively does this manager build and maintain a high-quality hiring pipeline and onboarding experience?

behavioralAnchors.description: Team norms are implicit and inconsistent; new members struggle to understand expectations around communication, code quality, or collaboration
Some norms exist (coding standards, review expectations) but they are not actively reinforced or evolved as the team changes
Deliberately shapes team culture through explicit norms, modeling desired behaviors, and addressing norm violations constructively
Creates a psychologically safe environment where team members challenge ideas openly; culture attracts and retains strong engineers
Influences engineering culture beyond their own team; establishes norms and practices that define how the broader org collaborates and operates

gapQuestions: What are the top 3 cultural norms on your team, and how would a new hire learn about them in their first week?
When was the last time you addressed a behavior that was undermining team culture, and how did you handle it?
How do you actively foster psychological safety so that team members feel comfortable raising concerns or admitting mistakes?
How do you ensure that knowledge sharing and documentation are living practices on your team, not just one-time efforts that go stale?

feedbackQuestions.question: How intentionally do I shape and maintain team culture, and do I address cultural issues before they become entrenched?
Does your team have a healthy culture where you feel safe to take risks, raise concerns, and disagree openly?
How effectively does this manager build a team culture that supports collaboration, learning, and high performance?
How well does this manager cultivate a healthy team culture that aligns with organizational values and retains talent?

behavioralAnchors.description: Security and compliance are treated as afterthoughts; team has unresolved audit findings and no awareness of relevant regulatory requirements
Reacts to security issues and compliance requests but does not proactively integrate security practices into the development lifecycle
Integrates security reviews into design and code review processes; ensures team completes compliance training and addresses findings on schedule
Champions security as an engineering quality attribute; builds automated guardrails and drives threat modeling as a standard practice for new systems
Shapes org-wide security and compliance strategy; establishes frameworks that make secure-by-default the path of least resistance for all teams

gapQuestions: When was the last time your team conducted a threat model for a new feature or system, and what did it surface?
How do you ensure your team stays current on security best practices and compliance requirements relevant to your domain?
What automated security guardrails (static analysis, dependency scanning, secrets detection) does your team have in place, and when were they last reviewed?
Can you describe a time you advocated for security investment that competed with feature delivery timelines?

feedbackQuestions.question: How proactively do I integrate security and compliance into my team's engineering practices rather than treating them as external obligations?
Does your manager make security and compliance feel like a natural part of engineering work rather than an afterthought or burden?
How well does this manager ensure their team's systems meet security and compliance standards without creating bottlenecks for partner teams?
How effectively does this manager maintain their team's security and compliance posture while balancing delivery priorities?

behavioralAnchors.description: Performance reviews are vague and perfunctory; all team members receive similar ratings regardless of impact; underperformance goes unaddressed
Provides differentiated ratings but feedback is generic; struggles to have direct conversations about underperformance or set clear improvement expectations
Delivers honest, evidence-based performance assessments; sets clear expectations and manages underperformance with documented improvement plans
Calibrates performance rigorously across the team; separates compensation decisions from developmental feedback; maintains a culture of continuous feedback
Influences org-wide calibration standards; designs performance frameworks that reward impact over activity and reduce bias in evaluation processes

gapQuestions: How do you differentiate between a strong performer and an exceptional performer on your team, with specific examples?
When was the last time you put someone on a performance improvement plan, and what was the outcome?
How do you ensure your performance assessments are based on evidence and impact rather than recency bias or personal affinity?
How do you handle the conversation when a high performer receives feedback that they are not yet ready for promotion?

feedbackQuestions.question: How consistently do I provide honest, evidence-based performance feedback, even when the message is difficult to deliver?
Does your manager provide fair and transparent performance assessments with specific examples, and do you understand where you stand?
How effectively does this manager calibrate performance on their team and address performance issues constructively?
How well does this manager conduct rigorous, fair performance evaluations and manage underperformance decisively?
